projects.title: NeuroSift
projects.subtitle: MRI Classification Pipeline (End-to-End)
projects.description: Development of a complete processing chain for medical image analysis using Deep Learning. Simulation of a diagnostic aid pipeline.
projects.longDescription: In daily radiological workflows, the manual sorting of MRI sequences (T1, T2, FLAIR) is a time-consuming and repetitive task, yet essential prior to any diagnosis. NeuroSift aims to automate this upstream 'triage' step, allowing practitioners to dedicate their expertise to pathological analysis rather than data management. The major technical objective was to design a realistic 'end-to-end' infrastructure capable of simulating a clinical production environment. The pipeline thus manages the complete lifecycle of medical data: from the automated ingestion of complex cohorts (Glioblastoma) and DICOM metadata cleaning, to advanced pre-processing normalizing inter-machine variabilities, finally delivering reliable predictions via an ergonomic radiologist interface.

steps.title: 1. Ingestion & Data Engineering
steps.content: Development of an automated extraction pipeline via the TCIA API to dynamically retrieve the UPENN-GBM cohort. The system parses the often chaotic native DICOM tree to structure a clean, hierarchical local Data Lake (Patient > Study > Series).

steps.title: 2. Advanced Medical Pre-processing
steps.content: Handling raw data unsuitable for classic CNNs. I implemented 16-bit reading via Pydicom followed by Adaptive Percentile Normalization (1-99%) to harmonize contrasts between different MRI machines, before final conversion to standardized 8-bit format.

steps.title: 3. Modeling (Deep Learning)
steps.content: Adoption of a Transfer Learning strategy on a ResNet18 architecture to overcome 'Small Data' limitations. Training uses Adam optimizer and Cross-Entropy Loss, validated by a strict 'Patient-Level Split' to ensure the model generalizes to new anatomies without memorization.

steps.title: 4. Infrastructure & MLOps
steps.content: Design of a 'Cloud-Ready' Micro-services architecture orchestrated by Docker Compose. The system includes decoupled image storage via MinIO (S3-compatible), a PostgreSQL database for metadata, and an interactive Streamlit interface for the clinician.

challenges.title: Contrast Bias (Semantic Ambiguity)
challenges.content: A T1 series with Gadolinium injection incorrectly classified as FLAIR (Confidence > 99%). The model learned hyper-intensity (white) as a FLAIR signature, missing the acquisition protocol context.

challenges.title: Distribution Drift (Edge Case)
challenges.content: Performance drop (Confidence ~50%) on orbital cuts (skull base). These areas contain structures (eyes, sinuses) under-represented in the brain-centered dataset, illustrating an Out-of-Distribution case.

projects.title: BioSeq-Analyzer
projects.subtitle: Bioinformatics Analysis Suite & Protein Characterization
projects.description: An interactive platform unifying multimodal sequence analysis. From pair-wise DNA alignment to structural protein characterization via UniProt.
projects.longDescription: Biological sequence analysis often requires juggling between obscure command-line scripts and fragmented web portals. BioSeq-Analyzer centralizes these workflows in a robust Streamlit application. Designed to facilitate genomic and proteomic exploration, the tool allows researchers to statistically validate sequence alignments, dynamically translate nucleic acids into proteins (ORF finding), and automatically retrieve rich functional metadata. The architecture relies on seamless integration of major domain APIs (NCBI Entrez, UniProt), transforming raw FASTA data into actionable biological insights (AlphaFold 3D structures, associated literature, functional domains) in a few clicks.

steps.title: 1. Ingestion & Algorithmic Alignment
steps.content: Support for standard FASTA format with parsing via Biopython. Implementation of configurable global (Needleman-Wunsch) and local (Smith-Waterman) alignment algorithms. Addition of a statistical validation layer using Monte-Carlo method (50+ shuffles) to distinguish real biological similarities from random noise.

steps.title: 2. Structural Visualization (Dotplots)
steps.content: Development of a customized matrix visualization engine (Dotplot) with Matplotlib. The user can filter visual noise by dynamically adjusting sliding window sizes and stringency thresholds to reveal repeats, inversions, and conserved domains.

steps.title: 3. Translation & ORF Discovery
steps.content: Open Reading Frame (ORF) detection algorithm on 6 frames (Forward/Reverse). The system intelligently identifies the most probable protein candidate (based on length and START/STOP codons) and allows cross-validation via BLASTN against RefSeq transcriptomic databases.

steps.title: 4. Functional Enrichment (UniProt)
steps.content: Real-time connection to the UniProtKB API to enrich identified sequences. The application aggregates and presents in a structured manner: subcellular localization, associated pathologies, InterPro domains, and links to AlphaFold structure predictions.

challenges.title: State Management & API Latency
challenges.content: Synchronous querying of massive databases (NCBI BLAST) can freeze the interface. I had to implement fine-grained Streamlit `session_state` management and caching mechanisms to preserve user experience fluidity while handling timeouts and rate limiting.

challenges.title: Alignment Score Normalization
challenges.content: A raw alignment score is difficult to interpret without context. Integrating the randomization test (shuffling) required optimizing Numpy calculation loops to generate a reference distribution on the fly without impacting tool reactivity.

projects.title: Patient Performance Overview
projects.subtitle: Hospital Analytics Dashboard & KPIs
projects.description: Business Intelligence dashboard for hospital performance monitoring. Multidimensional analysis of patient distribution, departmental efficiency, and satisfaction.
projects.longDescription: In a high-pressure hospital environment, visibility into patient flow is critical. This Power BI project transforms raw admission and treatment data into actionable insights. The report enables administrators to track key indicators (Average Length of Stay, Occupancy Rate, Satisfaction) in real-time and filter these metrics by department or practitioner. The interface is designed for intuitive navigation, simulating a web application experience within the BI tool.

steps.title: 1. Star Schema Modeling
steps.content: Design of a robust data model: separation of fact tables (Admissions, Consultations) and dimensions (Time, Patients, Departments) to ensure fast cross-filtering performance.

steps.title: 2. Advanced DAX Measures
steps.content: Development of complex DAX measures for dynamic KPIs: Time Intelligence (YTD, YoY), moving averages for trends, and calculation groups for dynamic metric switching.

steps.title: 3. Design & Navigation
steps.content: Creation of a fluid user experience using Bookmarks and navigation buttons. Use of custom backgrounds (Figma) to break away from the standard Power BI 'grid' look.

steps.title: 4. Patient Journey Analysis
steps.content: Visualization of care pathway bottlenecks via decomposition trees and service performance matrices.
